p.strong: Department of Public Health and Human Services

span.span: Public Health & Safety » Communicable Disease Epidemiology » Diseases A to Z » Coronavirus

strong.span: For assistance, you may Email or call the Joint Information Center 1-888-333-0461

img.alt: What to Do If Sick CDC.gov
img.title: What to Do If Sick CDC.gov

img.alt: Map and Demographic information for COVID-19 cases in Montana
img.title: Map and Demographic information for COVID-19 cases in Montana

h2.a: COVID-19 Testing Information for the Public

div.h3: If you are a member of the public and are concerned about getting tested for COVID-19, please contact your primary care provider.

p.strong: Montana state and local public health officials are monitoring the novel coronavirus disease (COVID-19) situation very closely. Governor's Coronavirus Task Force

div.p: To help prevent the spread of COVID-19 and other respiratory illnesses, you can take simple steps to protect yourself and your family:

ul.li: Follow Governor Bullock's Directive to stay at home to slow the spread of COVID-19,
Avoid contact with sick people when possible,
Cover your cough and sneezes with the crook of your elbow or a tissue
Avoid touching your eyes, nose and mouth and wash your hands frequently
Clean and disinfect frequently touched objects and surfaces using a regular household cleaning spray or wipe

div.p: Call ahead to a healthcare professional if you develop a fever and symptoms of respiratory illness, such as cough or difficulty breathing.
div.h3: You can contact your local county or tribal health department for questions regarding COVID-19, testing or what may be occurring in your community.
Addictive and Mental Disorders Division Information

li.a: COVID-19 Resources for Individuals, Families, and Providers
Executive Orders and Directives from the Governor's Coronavirus Task Force

ul.li: DPHHS HAN message 4/23/2020: Update and Interim Guidance on Outbreak of Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19)

DPHHS HAN message 01/13/2020: CDC Notification of Outbreak of Pneumonia of Unknown Etiology (PUE) in Wuhan, China

div.p: Human coronaviruses are common throughout the world. There are several types of coronaviruses including those that cause symptoms of the common cold. Human coronaviruses commonly cause mild to moderate illness. A novel, or new coronavirus is a strain of coronavirus that has not been identified before. This has happened previously with MERS-CoV and SARS-CoV both of which cause more severe respiratory illnesses.

A novel coronavirus is a new coronavirus that has not been previously identified. The virus causing coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19), is not the same as the coronaviruses that commonly circulate among humans and cause mild illness, like the common cold.

A diagnosis with coronavirus 229E, NL63, OC43, or HKU1 is not the same as a COVID-19 diagnosis. Patients with COVID-19 will be evaluated and cared for differently than patients with common coronavirus diagnosis.

The virus is still being studied and public health officials are learning more each day. To date, it appears that transmission occurs via respiratory droplets produced when an infected person coughs or sneezes as is the case with other respiratory illnesses like the common cold or influenza.
div.h2: What are the symptoms of COVID-19?
div.p: Patients with this novel coronavirus have reported mild to severe respiratory illness with cough, fever, and/or shortness of breath.
div.h2: How can I help protect myself and my family?
div.p: The best way to prevent infection is to avoid being exposed to the virus. The same preventative measures that are recommended during cold and flu season will also help to protect against COVID-19:

ul.li: Wash your hands thoroughly and often
Avoid touching your eyes, nose, and mouth
Cover your cough/sneeze with a tissue (or your elbow)
Stay home if you are sick
Clean and disinfect frequently touched objects and surfaces

div.p: The Montana Public Health Laboratory now has the capability to test for COVID-19 but the number of tests available is limited. We ask that providers consult with local public health and DPHHS to determine if an individual meets the criteria for testing.
Specific guidance for specimen collection and transport is found at the Montana Public Health Laboratory website.

div.p: To submit a question or comment to the Communicable Disease Epidemiology Program, please click on the suggestion box to access our online form.
Other Program Areas

p.em: The DPHHS CDEpi Section mission is to create, maintain, support, and strengthen routine surveillance and detection systems and epidemiological investigation processes, as well as to expand these systems and processes in response to incidents of public health significance.
